39350672.review:
An excellent Arkanoid-style block breaking action game that addresses nearly all the shortcomings of the genre while displaying a level of production values that far exceeds its $0.99 price tag. 

The graphics bright and colorful, evoking memories of some lost 32-bit era cult classic with expertly designed and animated sprites to match. Sound design follows suit with catchy music, striking sound effects, and voice samples that lend this title an extra bit of arcadey flair.

I was also pleased at the extra care put into balancing the difficulty of this game over Bot Vice; while the former title clearly expects players to perch squarely on the edge of their seats through each teeth-grittingly chaotic stage, Strikey Sisters takes a much more leisurely approach. Enemies attack less frequently, bullets move more slowly, and in general the hazards present in stages are much easier to identify as the screen is much less crowded thanks to the increased play area. That isn't to say that Strikey Sisters isn't still a challenge; you still have limited chances to clear a stage, and once you run out of lives you'll need to restart from scratch.

Still, Strikey Sisters does an excellent job of addressing the inherently random nature of clearing blocks by giving the player more direct control over directing the ball, providing a variety of powerups that are useful in both attacking enemies, defending against bullets, and clearing blocks off the playfield. When used correctly this greatly cuts down on the amount of down time the player has waiting for the ball to return.

DYA Games even manages to fit in some extra replay value in the form of Gems and the Bestiary; in each stage there is one Gem to collect, and throughout the stages you can pick up the Card spell which allows you to "capture" an enemy to add it to your collection percentage. While it doesn't do much to extend the gamplay for someone simply looking to finish all the stages, anyone who deems themselves a completionist will appreciate the gesture.

If you appreciate arcade-style games with tight controls and top-tier production value I would definitely recommend checking this out, especially for the price.

39001188.review:
[i]Status: All levels beaten (including Secret ones) and All bosses defeated[/i]

Bought it on Steam sale some days ago and it already became one of my favourite games. Didn't get into Super Star Path and still lurking around Bot Vice trying to figure out if that one is up my valley, but definitely can say that Sisters is an amazing game, especially in co-op.

Extremely great looking (top notch pixel art which looks on the same level as AAA SNES games back in a day), intensely fun, well thought out and really, really polished.

The story is the weakest point though, it looks like it desperately tries to copy Disgaea, but fails miserably and misses all marks possible. The actors did a good job with that was provided to them, but hearing them reading such texts is...ehhhhh, better be skipping it.

The game has many bosses, some of which are pretty challenging. Besides taunting the player(s), they also make funny sounds when the ball hits them, most likely these will stay with you for quite a while.

Beaten in 5~ hours (before unlocking four more secret levels) and wish there was more of it. Sequel, perhaps?

38898257.review:
A pretty darn decent breakout game, I had more fun with this than Wizorb due to it's faster pace though it had some frustrating moments. The soundtrack really makes it feel like a long lost PC Engine CD game, it feels retro without going the obvious chiptune route.  The story is pretty amusing with some good voice acting barring one of the main sisters who is just kind of grating. You can turn off the cut scene voices but unfortunately not the in-game ones which is a shame as the bosses voices are incredibly repetitive.

The bosses are a pain in the backside simply because they have too many hit poinys, can only be hit from the back and constantly move (sometimes dodging and teleporting) making it very time consuming and almost pure luck to hit them with the ball. 

I also wish the game was clear about how you unlock some hidden levels as it doesn't explain that you have to grab enough coins in some levels for a blue chest to appear with a key inside. Comparing mymap to a complete map on the Steam coummnity was the only way I could tell where these hidden levels were: there needs to be a padlock or something to give you a hint where to go to get keys.

All in all a bit flawed in spots but for how cheap it is it's definitely one of the better breakout genre games on Steam.

38389943.review:
DYA Games excels at creating old arcade / retro styled games with new twists.

Strikey Sisters is a fantasy-themed Breakout game, where you essentially bounce a ball from your paddle off of other objects, and win by destroying all of the blocks without losing your ball off the bottom of the level.

This is much more than that. There are a bunch of different monsters, levels, different powerups that affect your ball and character, boss battles. There's also Local Co-op!

The game is playable on a Keyboard, but a controller is recommended!


I highly recommend this to fans of retro games, especially breakout fans. It's very cheap as well, only $0.99! Go check out their other games too while you're at it, they're all the same price btw!

38361466.review:
I had initially purchased this game on a sale due to its low cost, simply assuming it as a Breakout clone and not much else. After deciding to go through my clogged library of Steam titles, I was plesently surprised to find the game to be pretty fun. 

Is it a Breakout clone? Yeah, it is, no doubt. However, for being that, it still manages to build on top of that and be a pretty fun romp. Graphically, it gives me a lot of iREM vibes, and the music is pretty cute for the tone the game is going for. I could probably go without some of the memey jokes thrown in, but that's something that's of a personal preference, but ultimately doesn't ruin the game. I wouldn't say this a binge game, personally, but it's a fun game to take twenty to thirty minutes out of your day to just kick back and play.

For a game that only costs ninety-nine cents USD, I'd highly recommend giving it a try. I plan to keep an eye on this dev to see what future games they make.

38239693.review:
Bonjour a tous, 

Ah arkanoid..... Qu'elle bon jeu, surtout quand celui ci as etait representé de toutes les manieres a toutes les sauces et sous toutes les formes et ce depuis longtemps deja. Mais revenons a notre sujet ...

Comme dit plus haut celui ci est un arkanoid like avec un gameplay pas tres originale et des graphismes assez basique pour le coup et comme tout les jeux du genre. Mais celui ci presente toutefois un charme qui n'est pas negligeable. 

Vous controlez deux soeurs au choix, qui se doivent de reussir une mission quelconque et le encore rien d'originale, mais ce qui rend le jeu interessant, c'est deja que cest un arkanoid mais aussi que le jeu est tres mignons  et les couleurs bien choisis. Sortileges, coup charger et speciaux, accessoires vous seront utiles de meme qu'amasser les differents tresors des differents niveaux que proposes le jeu pour les succés mais aussi atteindre les 100%. 

Le jeu est difficile et souvent punitif si vous n'avez pas assez de reflexe et de concentration voir rageant a pas mal de moment. "Die and retry" si je puis me permettre ses termes ou "meurs et recommence" en bon FR. 
Mais meme si la difficulté est elevé et le jeu resistant aux assaults repetés ! 
Rien n'est meilleurs que le moment ou vous mettez le dernier coup de balle dans la derniere pierre ou le dernier monstre qui vous barre le chemin du succés !!! 

Enfin tres bon petit jeu qui vaut toutefois bien son prix, amusant de temps a autres, redondant certe mais attachant quand aussi. Y'as quand meme un travail sur ce jeu et rien est laissé au hazard. 

Donc bon defouloir, a recommandé aux fans du genre meurs et reviens demain ou aux petits curieux qui cherche des jeux pas forcement cher et qui veulent s'amuser et bien sur aux fans du genre arkanoid.

Pour ma part je m'amuse bien de temps a autres donc je le recommande. 

Merci de me lire et  bon jeu.

38208915.review:
难以置信游戏开发者把当年在黑白屏上玩的打砖块进化成了现在的样子，有点找回当年在街机厅玩炸弹人的感觉了，很可惜不能识别我的街机摇杆。这是一款街机风格的类打砖块游戏，游戏分为普通关卡和Boss战关卡。普通关卡和传统打砖块一样，必须清理掉场上所有砖块才能过关，当然在这款游戏里还得清理完场上的怪物。而Boss战只需要击败Boss头目就行了，顺便值的一提是Boss战前的过场动画还蛮有趣的。

如果硬要说缺点的话那就是开发者你发行得太晚啦！你要早一两年发行的话我在大学宿舍和室友以及好基友啥的又多了一项娱乐活动，游戏时间数上百小时妥妥的。现在你让我找人和我一起玩还真是困难。有爸妈吧，他们对游戏有偏见，有个姐吧，她又不怎么玩游戏，有个妹吧，她又距离我太远啦！唉，只能寄希望于以后有了妻子和孩子同她们一起玩耍了。总之这游戏十分合我的胃口，两个人玩的话应该会很有趣吧，嘿嘿嘿。

38205951.review:
Amazing brick brock game with RPG elements !
You can either play alone or with a teammate.

Your goal is to destroy every block and then kill the remaining ennemies to finish a level.
Every block you destroy gives you a gold coin you can pick up.
Every ennemy killed gives you a powerful bonus item.
When having 50% of total coins, a green chest appears : it contains a green card which can be thrown to an ennemy to add it to the bestiary.
At 60% total coins, you get a brown chest containing a green emeraude - one per level to collect !
For some levels containing secret locations, you need to get 70% of gold coins to get a blue chest (giving a key).

May seem difficult at first, but you'll quickly get better and addicted to it !
That game could have cost the double, it would still be worth it !
10/10

彩京の『ガンバリッチ』と言って何人に通じるのだろうか。
全実績解除+全コイン獲得した記念にレビュー。

いわゆるブロック崩しなんだけど、バーで弾を受けた反射角でブロックを崩すのではなく、スラッシュボタンでボールを打ち返すスタイル。
慣れてくるとかなり自由に弾を当てたい場所に狙うことが出来るので、ブロック崩しでありがちな残り１個に当てるまで何分も掛かるなんてことが無いのはとても良し。
真面目にボールでブロック壊すより、敵倒して落ちてくる魔法アイテム使うともっと難易度が下がる。
ボール加速もほとんど無く、とにかく遊びやすい。

Live2D主流になりつつある2Dゲームで、全てをドットで描ききっているのは非常に好感触。みんな可愛い。


良い点が多い反面、細かい不満点が魚の小骨みたいに残ったり。
・マップ移動はGamepadなのに、ステージ入るときにGamepad入力選択しないと操作を受け付けない。
・敵の弾と自分の弾の見分けがつきづらいステージがある。
・集めたコインに意味を持たせてほしかった。
・更に欲を言えばオンラインco-opできれば！

セール時に買ったんだけど、通常時に買えばよかったと思うぐらいによく出来た作品だと思う。というか安すぎじゃネ？

38104105.review:
Very nice game.

It is always great when you can tell the the developers had fun making a game, and put care into making a game.  Strikey Sisters shows that very well.  

All of the enemies are designed well, and provide the variation necessary to differentiate between the levels to make each stage feel unique.  

The bosses are challenging, and there is a surprising amount to discover as you start going through the game, but still have undiscoverd cutscenes and enemies left to find. 

The voice acting was done well, although it can sometimes be tedious to hear the boss attacks said over and over and over if you get stuck on a particulary difficult boss.

Two very minor things that happened in my playthrough, that I'm sure the developers are working to fix, is a few of the cutscenes had text missing from the text boxes, but the voice acting still said the words just fine.  And very super rarely, your ball might become stuck inside an enemy (only happened to me twice in 15 hours of playtime, and eventually the ball did unstick itself after a time).

Overall this game is super solidly made, great detail, fun story, pleasent asthetics, and you cannot beat the value the game will provide for the price tag.

37935979.review:
This is my new, favorite break-out / Arkanoid clone, no contest.  This game has a unique mechanic in which you can strike the ball, and use a charged-up hit that causes the ball to deal extra damage to blocks and enemies.

The game can be a bit difficult, as your character can take damage from both losing the ball, as well as taking damage from enemies.  However, the challenge is actually quite refreshing; every level you beat feels like it was a worthwhile challenge.

As a classic / old school game fan, I have to say this game has top-notch pixel art, very catchy tunes, and overall really fun and solid gameplay.

37859577.review:
My review on Strikey Sisters

I must say that DYA Games done again an amazing job in making such a well polished game.  When I started up the game, it brought me into that memory of my youth when played those many arcade games back in the days, which they where all great times for me.  This game from DYA Games, has given me so much motivation to go and create a full cabinet arcade system to have at home.

Strikey Sisters brings many other game element styles into the mix.  You got the map to choose which levels areas you want to start off from. just like Super Mario Brothers 3.  With the gameplay style of Brick Breaker arcade gameplay, which i was very impress that this game was that kind of gameplay, but with action style in the mix.  It also give that pixel arcade style feel and look.  That fans of retro games, will surely enjoy, with good sound effects and good music too.

The game is also a local two player co-op, which you and friend can play as ether one of the two sisters.  Marie and Elene.  Which they both do the same attack style when you press the attack button.  But they do not look or sound the same.  The story of the game, is very interesting and funny.  All character designs and look, just give you those old time nostlagia feel when playing a game back in the days on the consoles like nintendo & sega genesis system.

Art design of the game is so right on with the pixel graphic look, of those retro games back in the days.  As i mention before anyone enjoy the retro games of times past before, will feel right at home with this game.  The game also as many other features, such as changing the difficult from easy to hard and etc.  

Now to the pros and cons

Pros+

+Good Story

+Amainzg Pixel Art Style

+Good Soundtrack & Sound Effects

+Great Fun Gameplay

+Hours of play

+Local 2 Player Co-op

Cons-

-Nothing to complain

So this is my review of the Strikey Sisters.  Would i recommend this game to a family or friend?  Yes i would, is it worth the full price?  Yes it is, but if you are still unsure if paying full price is worth it.  Then wait for a sale but in honest truth, it not that pricey which wouldn't break your wallet or purse at all.

Hope this helps anyone that has been wondering if the game is worth it or not.

36668222.review:
Strikey Sisters is basically "just a breakout" clone, but a very well made one at that. There's an overworld to explore, bosses to beat, as well as things to collect. The graphics look gorgeous and the controls work really well, considering that there is no mouse control. For the asking price it's definitely worth a look, especially when it's on sale of course.

But be prepared to be kicked around by the bosses. In addition to control your ball you also have to evade the ordinary enemies and their attacks, as well as the bosses' attacks all the while trying to hit the bosses with your measly sized ball while they move around. If you ever played breakout you know, how long it can sometimes take to hit that last stupid brick, now imagine it moving as well. Just infuriating. With a bit of patience and a lot of luck you can do it though and even though it's quite a big gripe, I'd still recommend the game, since there are plenty of levels to enjoy.

36458403.review:
Well, what can I say. The game is a Breakout/Arkanoid clone at its core but with a "ship" that can attack and very tricky and cunning enemies that will make you think a bit outside of the box. The challenge on Normal and above will keep you on your toes. The storyline is basically Touhou level of an excuse to beat everyone up during an incident. In short, it contains enough acid to be good. Special mention to the voice acting, which makes it for an entertaining ride too, much like Bot VIce and Super Star Path.

Another good point are the boss battles, which bring a welcomed variety to the mix and will also give you more than a headache if you come unprepared.

Sporting very vibrant and welcoming pixel art that exudes love and care, Strikey Sisters is definitely going to provide quite a few hours of entertainment without asking you to go crazy all over impossible feats. (Although try capturing all monsters, an underlying mechanic that will keep you replaying stages to collect that one last pesky mob that dared to escape your capture cards.)

I hope the soundtrack is released soon because it's very good! (Same for Bot Vice OST, which is actually perhaps even better)

36236056.review:
At it's core, its Brickbreaker.

Pros:
+Great visuals.  Really feels like a SNES game
+Music is good
+Fun boss fights
+Above average difficulty (though pretty soft compared to Bot Vice)

Cons:
-Story/writing is lackluster.  But this game isn't played for the story/writing anyway.
-No unlockables
-Local co-op only
-Gameplay can get monotonous FAST

I really wish there were more powerups.  Not only that, but it would be cool to see specific enemies drop specific powerups.  Some enemies are very unique, others don't feel that way aside from their apperance.  Giving them specific item drops would give the enemies more depth (sort of like in the Castlevania games).

I don't really see myself re-playing this game again, however.  I played it enough and sometimes I felt like just playing Bot Vice because the game's pace can drop drastically when you are aiming for the last remaining brick to break, or the last enemy to kill.

Bot Vice was great, this game was ok.  I recommend it when it goes on sale.  I wouldn't pay full price for this game, but I would pay full price for Bot Vice.  So check that out.

もしsteamのなかで発売されているブロック崩しゲームの中で何か一本お薦めを尋ねられた場合、自分はこのゲームをお薦めします。

このゲームの特徴として、ブロック崩しゲームでありながらボールを打ち返す動作で敵を攻撃したり溜め動作で防御、敵弾を跳ね返したり出来るなどアクションゲーム＋ブロック崩しの融合を果たしている点が非常にユニークです。

ブロック崩しにおける重要なファクター、ボールの速度に関して。動体視力を超えるぐらい速くなったりはせず、やや低速、控え目な感じでゲーム的な重心はブロックを崩しながらの敵との攻防が中心であると感じます。敵キャラは非常に多種多様な攻撃手段を持ち、非常にトリッキーな手段で主人公達を苦しめます。

敵のデザインも小憎らしくく、でもキュートなデザインです。声優の方の実力が確かなのか、とても可愛い印象があります。1ステージクリアごとに進行状況は記憶されるので疲れた時はすぐ辞められ、気分転換に始めたいときにはすぐに始められる。シンプルで遊びやすい良いゲームとなっています。サクッとブロック崩しを楽しみたい人、興味が沸いた方は是非買ってみてください。思ったより楽しめますよ。

36125931.review:
Edit: After some more time with the game, I've caught on to the flow of things, and while I still think some things could be a tad less frustrating, it was mostly a case of getting good. Really enjoying it now. 

All the ingredients for a solid game are here, but unfortunately I'm finding it a little frustrating. The stages are too small vertically. You play very close to the blocks, which means it's easy to toss the ball behind you accidentally, and the unbreakable blocks tend to be annoyingly in the way too often. I would also argue that you move too slow. Especially if you consider getting all the coins. Each block drops a coin down to you when broken, and each level shows you how many coins you've collected in it. Getting all of them in one stage is frustrating and takes a lot away from the fun of the game, because using power ups can cause blocks to break all over the place and you'll never be able to get all of them at once, not to mention the need to catch the ball. Getting 100% completion would be a nightmare.

Aesthetically this game is fantastic. Looks, sounds and feels like a 16-bit arcade classic. I would guess that the game was inspired by the SNES game Firestriker, because it's sort of a beefed up version of that, although not so much in terms of gameplay. I was actually really hoping it would be more like Firestriker, because that game did this sort of thing incredibly well, in my opinion. But the premise here is still good. And for the $1.13 I spent on it I'm willing to look past some of things I'd consider flaws and recommend it.

36042167.review:
Strikey Sisters bringt frischen Wind in das Brickbreaker-Genre!

Ihr spielt allein oder mit einem Kumpel und kämpft euch auf einer an Marioworld erinnernden Map durch diverse Levels. Das Ziel ist es, mittels Bewegung auf der x-Achse und einem Angriffs-, sowie Spezialattacken-Button alle Blöcke zu eleminieren. Dabei helfen euch die Power-Ups, welche ihr vom Zerstören der generischen (beweglichen) Einheiten erhaltet, die aber gleichzeitig versuchen, euch das Leben schwer zu machen. 

Weiterhin werdet ihr Bosskämpfe bestreiten, bei denen die Vernichtung des Bosses das Level beendet - unabhängig von zerstörten Blöcken.

Die Gegner sind abwechslungsreich gestaltet und das Spiel weist eine hohe Dynamik auf. Wer seine Reflexe auf die Probe stellen möchte, ist hier goldrichtig!

Der Schwierigkeitsgrad (ich selbst spiele auf "mittel") ist knackig - dennoch erlebe ich keine Frustration, auch nach dem zehnten Versuch, ein Level zu schlagen. Das mag an der enormen Kurzweiligkeit durch ein gekonntes Gameplay-Design liegen.

Ich kann das Spiel uneingeschränkt empfehlen. Im Steam-Sale für 99 Cent ein echtes Juwel!

34385412.review:
So far into the game, I can definitely recommend it. It plays like a more complicated and engaging version of Atari Breakout. It has most of the pros and cons of a brick breaker, meaning that I'd recommmend it to people who already enjoy the genre.

Pros:
 - Quick-paced and keeps you on your toes with enemies and lots of collectibles
 - Great amount of enemy variety and powerups that all do different things
 - AWESOME graphical style
 - Difficulty options
 - Lots of levels to play through
 - Good sense of accomplishment after beating every level

Cons:
 - Though it is unavoidable in the genre, the endgame of each level can last for a long time. The game does compensate for this with some of its powerups.
 - There is no real acknowledgement for finishing levels/collecting things on a higher difficulty. Some people might be incentivized to play on the easiest mode the whole time (which I wouldn't imagine to be too much easier, because I'd think it would make levels take longer+there would be less powerups; probably mroe of a "beginner" mode). The normal difficulty is recommended, and it is is what I'm going to play with the whole time, but it would be nice to have some sort of incentive to play on the higher difficulty.

It's still a lot more fun than most games, and it's worth the price.

34069444.review:
Strikey Sisters est un petit jeu bourré de bonnes choses, et qui bénéficie d'une réalisation presque irréprochable. Ce casse-briques ambiance "sorcières & monstres" est des plus réussi, tant sur le plan esthétique que musical, mais c'est surtout son impeccable jouabilité simple et agréable qui en font un jeu immédiatement fun.
Le scénettes scénaristiques sont assez amusantes, et les sous-titres sont dans un français nickel..

Quelques suggestions cependant :[list]
    [*]-Le jeu ne mémorise pas les réglages du périphériques / choix de personnages, et lance le jeu "au clavier" prioritairement. Et ce, même si on y joue exclusivement au pad depuis le début. Il faut donc indiquer le périphérique à chaque début de partie, et c'est un peu dommage que ça ne soit pas sauvegardé avec le reste.
    [*]-Dans le didacticiel, aucune indication sur la façon de débloquer les animations dans le bestiaire... [i](Pour ceux qui se poseraient la question, il faut apparemment "capturer" les monstres en leur jetant l'espèce de carte magique qu'on trouve dans les coffres, et qui les fait disparaitre quand ça les touche...)[/i]
    [*]-J'ai personnellement trouvé que les doublages un peu pénibles desservaient les scénettes, qui sont pourtant plutôt sympathiques et rigolotes... Pouvoir désactiver les voix dans les options serait cool.
[i]Des bruitages rétro (façon "Golden Sun" par exemple) auraient été parfaits en guise de voix pour ce style de jeu je trouve! Mais bon - on ne va pas trop se plaindre des doublages pour un casse-briques 100% arcade! ^^[/i]
    [*]-Pour vraiment pinaller sur des détails, je dirais que ça aurait été sympa que les bonus puissent se "cumuler": quand on prend "double ball", la balle se divise en deux. Mais si on en reprend un juste après, "double ball" reste juste "double ball"... j'aurais bien aimé qu'il y ait 4 balles, puis 8 etc... 
    [*]-Ça aurait été intéressant de pouvoir "stocker" jusqu'à 2 ou 3 magies, et les sélectionner avec RB et LB... (Pour pouvoir précisément stocker la "carte à bestiaire", lorsqu'il n'y a pas le monstre convoité à l'écran).
[/list]

Il m'aura fallu 7h pour le terminer tranquillement, ce qui est plutôt honnête à 8€, sachant que ce type de jeu dispose d'une excellente rejouabilité (et qu'il dispose en plus d'un mode 2 joueurs en local).
De plus, pour les complétionnistes, trouver tous les niveaux secrets, capturer chaque monstre, et terminer chaque level avec toutes les pièces & emeraudes constituera un défi plutôt ardu, qui vous occupera pour un bout de temps!
Les petites broutilles signalées plus haut ne nuisent en rien au plaisir de jouer et rejouer au jeu en l'état, et pour ma part, je trouve ce Strikey Sisters vraiment très plaisant !

33610039.review:
A mixed bag of a breakout clone, but the sum of its parts ultimately makes it a good purchase.  DYA games tends to make very fun pixel games with an arcade feel and Strikey Sisters is no different. It has a nice, upbeat soundtrack, fun additions to the breakout gameplay with the spells and abilities added in, collectibles galore, and some truly interesting boss battles.  I also give the game credit for having full voice acting.  It is hit and miss in places, going at times too shrill anime, but...credit for trying, some of it is pretty fun.

Now, the mixed bag part.  This is a breakout game through and through, which means it has all the frustrations of hitting a ball over and over again to try and kill the last enemy hiding in a corner or the last block hidden in a corner.  That is incredibly lame.  Also, while the abilities and additions are nice, there aren't enough evolutions to remove the frustration.  Likewise, it's annoying that some enemies can just hit the ball away or hide with their back to the wall to prevent you from advancing.  Finally, you can get multiple of the less fun upgrades, of which only about half are really enjoyable.  Also, despite having collectibles, aside from the bestiary, you can't tell how many emeralds you've got, keys, or whatever from each stage.  All you get is an arbitrary percentage marker.

So, frustrations aside, do I recommend?  Well, yeah.  It's oozing with charm and if you like Breakout, you can do much worse.  Frankly, I like the arcade gameplay better than Wizorb or other Breakout contemporaries.  Buy it if you can deal with Breakout and all its issues because it's a pretty fun.

33340980.review:
A perfect throwback to the SNES/Genesis era with a simple, but fun premise. It is so addicting! It brings a very fun spin to brick breaker games, adding a little bit o strategy to it. I also appreciate that you can do co-op in the main campaign as well (as opposed to being restricted to only a 2 player mode like some other retro games I played recently) making this game tons of fun to spend hours on end playing with a friend.

If you do not have a local friend to play with, the single player is equally fun, if not a bit more challenging, as you have twice the area to cover with a single character.

Getting this one was a very nice surprise, and I'm glad I decided to give it a try! Such a fun game with lots of charm. ♥

[h1] Strikey Sisters——中老年休闲打砖块游戏	[/h1]
     DYA Games的三款作品，都是质量很高的像素风格游戏。其中，本人最喜欢Strikey Sisters，[strike] 因为难度最低	[/strike]。
     Strikey Sisters 是一款将RPG元素与打砖块相结合的游戏。打砖块是一款经典的益智游戏，将经典玩法与RPG元素结合的游戏，本人玩过的并不多，印象比较深的有两款，分别是《噗哟噗哟xTetris》以及《Puzzle Quest》（三消与RPG结合的益智游戏）。经典的玩法引入一些新玩法和要素，个人觉得是一种不错的尝试。任何游戏都要进步，老游戏亦是如此，这样不仅能吸引玩家，还能为游戏续命。
     与传统打砖块不同，由于加入了类似RPG的战斗元素，使得游戏与传统打砖块相比，有了自己的特色。击败怪物可以获得道具奖励，可以攻击怪物或用于消除方块，让打砖块不再是单纯的撞击与接球。
Pros：
     +像素风，像素点细腻，色彩柔和，看着很舒适。
     +操作简单，难度适中。游戏整体节奏不算快，玩起来并不是很累，很休闲。
     +道具与怪物多样，包含简单的收集要素，怪物图鉴需要使用特定道具击中怪物获得。
     +支持本地COOP。
     +全程语音演出，质量还不错。
Cons：
     -敌人的攻击均可抵消，降低了游戏的难度。加上游戏难度不可调，不够过瘾（？）。

总体说来，游戏整体质量不错，推荐给喜欢像素风格游戏以及休闲游戏的玩家。

8/10

32617890.review:
简短说，这游戏框架上就是个打砖块游戏，和传统打砖块游戏相比的特色
1.本体。不是托盘，而是可爱的小魔女，有两种接球方式，一个是直接用身体接，其实接球判定还是足够宽的，比模型宽的，另一个是用攻击把球打回去，判定更远更宽，还可以通过走位把球按照希望的路线拍出去。
2.砖块。两种，传统的砖块和敌方怪物。传统砖块一般都需要球打中两次才会碎，碎后掉一个金币，需要去接住获取，当获取足够金币后，就会随机位置出现宝箱，球打中宝箱会掉宝物，宝物都是收集成就性质的，官方也表示如果不愿意玩收集可以不用纠结。怪物多种多样，对你放的技能也不同，有的会把飞过来的球拍回去，有的会向你扔子弹之类的，用球或者魔女近战攻击都可以打死
3.奖励道具。打死怪物后会掉奖励道具，比如吃了立刻被动生效的双球和加速，比如吃了可以先存起来主动施放的冲击波等等。
4.双人。可以二人分别控制两个魔女姐妹同场互助。
5.蓄力攻击。本作的核心操作，蓄力攻击可以把敌人的发射物拍回去打敌人，可以对近战敌人造成很大伤害，拍出去的球威力更大，可以一击打碎砖块，可以对怪物完成更多伤害。

大概就这些。另外，剧情也非常有趣，气氛很轻松，基本上就是两个熊孩子被一群熊大人给弄地十分无语的故事，最后是敌我和解的happy ending，请放心食用。

32528638.review:
Strikey Sisters is, at it's core, a simple brick breaking arcade game. But the package it's wrapped in as well as lots of neat little features make it something special.

The story is simple, retro video game faire. Two witch sisters lose their beloved pet and go about beating up monsters all over a fantasy kingdom to find him. It's very goofy and doesn't take itself seriously at all, which is just fine. Reminds you of something you would see in a 90's game.

The dialogue is fully voiced over to mixed results. The two sisters, as well as many of the characters, are enjoyable but many of them deliver lines with unusual pronunciation or tone. One jarring case is when a character's name is pronounced completely differently by two different characters. Another is when an actor's dialogue is clearly supposed to be interrupted but they finished their line as a complete sentence. I also learned that one actor played all the male characters. While that's a neat credit to have and some of his performances are fine, several are also weak and I think he was stretched too thin. 

At the end of the day, the gameplay is what matters and that's where Strikey Sisters shines! You move back and forth to knock a ball up and break blocks like many classic arcade games. What makes this stand out is you play in an arena full of monsters that hamper your progress. Some are simply obstacles while others attack you in interesting ways. Killing these monsters give you a variety of power ups that either enhance your ball, yourself, or affect monsters in some way. Bosses also keep things fresh and are often invincible from the front, so you must get creative in how you'll defeat them.

The simplest little feature that makes all the difference is your attack button. This one button allows you greater control of your ball's trajectory than most brick breakers. Not only that, you can use it to attack enemies close by. Not only that, you can use it to block enemy attacks. Not only THAT, you can charge your attack to hit your ball with greater force that breaks blocks and kill enemies faster. NOT ONLY THAT, your charged attack can deflect enemy projectiles. which is incredibly helpful for taking down bosses! It's a beautiful example of simple innovation. I love it when games can make one little feature very robust and useful. I think of the jump button in Downwell. 

Being that the gameplay is very simple, I find it a good thing that the game isn't overly long. I beat it (not 100%) in about 5 hours, and there's still unlockable levels and a bestiary to complete! I often found myself meaning to only sit down for a level or two, then found myself totally sucked in. I also found the difficulty to be fair and steadily increases throughout the story. 

The entire game has a beautiful, pixelated esthetic and is supported by catchy synth tunes! There aren't a ton of tracks but enough for the map, cutscenes, levels and boss fights and they get the job done! The entire game gave me a lot of nostalgic, warm fuzzy feelings! 

Overall, I highly enjoyed Strikey Sisters throughout. While I do have some production qualms, the game does exactly what it sets out to do beautifully. Credit also has to go out to the two brothers who made it. You guys created an excellent product that you both should be very proud of and you're officially on my radar now. This game is incredibly solid and, if you take everything you learn from the feedback, your next game should be fantastic. Great work to you both, and everyone else involved!

[h1]0 前言[/h1]

这款游戏主要来讲就是弹球类，不过不同于经典的平板弹球，其反弹的方式是主人公的攻击（虽然用身体也能，但是毕竟身体宽度小啊），在初版时没有蓄力和弹反，第一次更新后增加了这个功能。

32437900.review:
After playing the excellent Bot Vice here on Steam, I was looking forward to seeing the developer DYA Games' next game. Now it's here, and while I think that Bot Vice is still the better game of the two, Strikey Sisters is worth checking out for anyone who's interested in retro action!

Strikey Sisters is a pretty fun game that could be seen as a mix of action games and classic brick breaker style games.
Your characters are stuck at the bottom of the playing field (can only move left and right), and your job is to destroy all bricks and monsters by using the ball that bounces around. You'll also find several power-ups and attack spells to help you. If the enemies get close enough, you can still also melee attack them. Just like in classic brick breaking games, you are not allowed to let the ball go off screen, you will lose health if you do, so you'll need to be careful to not let that happen.

+ Fun gameplay
+ Good pixel art
+ Good music
+ Two player co-op
+ Funny story and dialog that doesn't take itself too seriously. Cutscenes also have voice acting. It is not always that great, but at least the main characters' voice actresses did a very good job. I'm actually really glad that the devs decided to have voice acting both in this game and Bot Vice, because it just gives the game so much personality!
+ Generally it's a polished game, just what I would expect from DYA games!

- Can get repeative after playing a while
- There can be moments when the ball is bouncing around in the back of the stage for a long times before it comes back to you, and meanwhile you don't really have much to do. It can also get frustrating when there is one unbroken brick left at some tricky location and you keep hitting the ball for a long time until you finally get it broken

32368221.review:
- [b]Versión corta[/b]:

Compra este juego ya mismo, lo pasarás genial.

- [b]Versión larga[/b]: 

Una de las mejores cosas que me sucedió como jugador el año pasado fue descubrir los juegos de [b]DYA Games[/b], gracias a una entrevista que les hicieron en [b][i]RetroManiac[/i][/b]. En aquel momento estaban a punto de lanzar su segundo juego para Steam, [b][i]Bot Vice[/i][/b], y me lancé sin pensarlo a por él. Lo que me encontré fue un juego que despedía olor a salón arcade por todos sus poros, y eso es algo que resuena muy fuerte en mi interior porque viví plenamente aquella época a mediados de los '80 y hasta su casi total desaparición en los '90. Así que [b][i]Bot Vice[/i][/b] me hizo confiar ciegamente en el buen hacer de DYA, y cuando anunciaron [b][i]Strikey Sisters[/i][/b] lo apoyé desde el primer momento. No me han decepcionado en absoluto.

Una semana después de comprar el juego ya me lo había pasado al 100%, y disfruté cada segundo. Me gustan mucho los machacaladrillos, y [b][i]Strikey Sisters[/i][/b] es el mejor que ha llegado a Steam desde [i]Wizorb[/i]. La ventaja frente al juego de Tribute Games está en una mayor accesibilidad e inmediatez: puedes ir fase a fase en un mundo abierto en el que nadie te dice cuál es el orden que debes seguir. Mientras hayas desbloqueado un nivel, puedes jugarlo, y si una fase se te resiste, puedes seguir jugando por otro camino. Así que nada de tener que superar una docena de fases y un [i]final boss[/i] del tirón. [b][i]Strikey Sisters[/i][/b] se presta a sesiones de juego cortas, como un buen arcade, y hay suficiente variedad en escenarios, enemigos, y jefes como para no aburrirse nunca al estar viendo siempre lo mismo. La mecánica de juego es sencilla y muy bien ajustada, y da lugar a momentos espectaculares gracias a la mezcla de ataques fuertes, hechizos, e ítems potenciadores. Además hay mucho que hacer aparte de superar todas las fases, como hacerse con la gema verde de cada nivel, descubrir todos los niveles secretos, o capturar todos los tipos de enemigo para completar el bestiario. Por supuesto, siendo obra de DYA Games, todo el apartado audiovisual es una delicia, desde los efectos sonoros que son puro arcade hasta los gráficos con cierto aire a juego de Super Nintendo.

Si te gustan los buenos arcades y los juegos mimados en cada uno de sus aspectos, no puedes dejar pasar [b][i]Strikey Sisters[/i][/b], una sobresaliente experiencia retro que te atrapará hasta su conclusión. Yo ya estoy deseando que [b][i]DYA Games[/i][/b] lance su cuarto juego.

[b]Worth It? YES[/b]

[h1]LIKES[/h1]
[list]
[*]Arcade style brick breaker game
[*]Adorable pixel-art graphics
[*]Classic Synth Soundtrack
[*]2 player couch co-op 
[*]Lots of different enemies, areas, and bosses
[*]Magic attacks and power ups for player and brick breaker ball
[*]Plays well on keyboard and Xbox controller
[/list]

[h1]DISLIKES[/h1]
[list]
[*]Graphics are not as smooth in full screen
[*]Cheesy dialog in cutscenes
[*]The brick breaker ball can be slow at times 
[*]Hard to direct the brick breaker ball
[/list]

[h1]The Final Word[/h1]

Brick breaker games have been around for a long time but you've never seen them like this before, welcome to Strikey Sisters.

From the get-go your strong attack will be your best friend. It will break bricks faster and reflect projectiles. Enemies will drop power ups and respawn until every brick has been destroyed. Power ups will come pouring down the screen, ranging from freezing enemies, lighting attacks, fire balls, bombs, and more. Not only will you need to collect power ups, but bricks will also drop coins which are needed to unlock treasure chests containing keys for secret levels and a monster catching ability. There is a cutscene and boss battle every 4 stages which are even more frantic and fun. Don't worry, missing your ball or getting hit 3 times only makes you restart the stage. The retro synth soundtrack fits perfectly with the charming pixel-art style.

DYA Games has done a fantastic job revamping an old time classic into a modern day action arcade brick-break breakout!

32280093.review:
Man, I loved this game! This is from the same Team that made Bot Vice which I also really enjoyed. 

The graphical style is similar with great pixel-art sprites and backgrounds. The gameplay is considerably different though. I found Bot Vice a bit more difficult too.

This one is a breakout/arkanoid style game where you smack a ball back and forth to destroy blocks while also fighting enemies and dodging their attacks. The goal in regular stages is to destroy all the blocks and then the remaining enemies who will keep respawning, trying to kill you, so long as there are still blocks on screen. You actually hit the ball with a slashing attack so you can control its direction if you hit it at certain angles. You can also charge your slash to hit the ball faster and also use it to reflect most enemy attacks which is very usefull. 

Then there's a boss battle every so often where you only have to diminish the boss's health bar instead of destroying every block. Boss battles are alot of fun and can be a bit intense IMO. Some of them I had to retry quite a few times. lol.

It has a light-hearted story with voiced cutscenes which I found amusing. The scenes are mostly before you fight one of the bosses.

The soundtrack rocks too. I felt the need to pick it up off bandcamp almost immediately lol. They brought back the same guy that did Bot Vice's music. 

It's even got a 2 player local co-op mode which is great if you have a buddy to play with! I've tried it both ways and enjoyed playing solo just as much personally. The main game's story lasted me about 8 hours and it took me another 2-3 to go back and collect all the achievements. I imagine I'll be revisiting it every so often since it's fun to play in short bursts.

Altogether this is a pretty cute slight twist on a brick-breaker style game.

Two things stand out as not-so-great, though.

There is a "power attack" where you hold the button to charge, but releasing does not attack.. an entirely second button press is necessary and constantly mashing and holding and tapping was kinda un-intuitive from what one would expect from normal gameplay tendencies and design.. not a huge one, but it was oddly annoying.

Second, the voice overs are incredibly unnecessary and downright annoying/bad. All of it is constant and lame pop-culture, fourth-wall breaking, etc.  Which isn't bad in and of itself, but bosses, for example, say their one or two "hilarious" references EVERY TIME they use an attack. The little bits of story are delivered via dialog and cutscenes of sorts, and is decently done, but so tacky and 'humor' focused that I just skipped it.

Honestly without the attempted humor that falls flat I'd recommend this more strongly, and all in all it's my feeling that it takes away from the game rather than add to it.

Sometimes there are too many projectiles and moving bits on screen such that the ball becomes utterly lost, but overall it's pretty fun. I'd liken it to Wizorb and that sorta thing. I didn't try the local co-op, but that's an option.

Ultimately I'd recommend it for what it does well - a pretty tightly controlled block breaker with a few twists - spells, attacks (you can charge-up and reflect enemy attacks, giving you more options to break/damage than just the ball(s)), even if the game is hindered a bit by a super over-the-top and bad attempt at humor, unnecessary voice overs that don't add anything, and the same tired, overdone constant barrage of stupid pop culture - repeated every few seconds by each boss to the point of ad nauseum.

32158822.review:
- Breakout: The next level -

Strikey Sisters demuestra la soberbia creando videojuegos de un equipo que poco a poco se va haciendo un nombre. Imaginad un Arkanoid o un Breakout venido a más, con poderes, secretos, jefes y una pequeña historia. Mucho más evolucionado y competente que aquel lejano título de SNES llamado Firestriker; el objetivo de este Strikey es destruir todos los ladrillos con una de las dos protagonistas (o ambas si se juega a dobles), golpear la pelotita y a su vez defenderse y atacar a los enemigos, sirviéndose del movimiento estándar o de la propia pelota. Hay tres tipos de power-ups que harán la tarea más sencilla. La palabra diversión es la clave: es divertido jugar, progresar, buscar secretos, capturar a los enemigos con el hechizo de la carta y descubrir el mapeado.

Lo bueno de S. Sisters es que no todo gira en torno a la pelota: podremos devolver los proyectiles enemigos a modo de contraataque, destruyendo así más ladrillos o a los propios rivales. Los jefazos se llevan la palma, originales a rabiar y todo ello siempre con un puntito de Bot Vice reconocible en cada gráfico, melodía e incluso en el sistema de juego. Sólido, de buena duración y con una dificultad perfecta, ni fácil ni difícil, notando partida a partida cómo vamos mejorando. Sobre el apartado gráfico, sublime pixel-art (estos chicos tienen una de las mejores manos haciendo este tipo de gráficos de España), y una enorme OST con un toque noventero que hará las delicias de los amantes de los 16-bits. Mimado hasta el extremo y hasta el último minuto de juego.

Ahí donde los veis, DYAGames se está convirtiendo en el estudio de referencia indie de mi país. Muchas gracias por hacer videojuegos tan increíbles y divertidos. 

PD: Enormes guiños a Bot Vice en cierto momento del videojuego, épico.

32152752.review:
[h1]Strikey Sisters is an absolute Steam gem.[/h1]

This unique ball-breaking puzzle fantasy action game is basically Arkanoid meets Popful Mail (or insert some other classic, charming Japanese action-RPG). It's fun, addictive & gorgeous... but [strike]still has a few issues.[/strike] 

[i]UPDATE 7/30/2017: I've since beaten this game in just under 5 hours and have enjoyed the latest versions. The devs at DYA Games really tweaked, polished and refined this thing via post-launch updates, and I have to say... it is a [b]PHENOMENAL[/b] title now. [/i]

I USED to have some slight issues, but they've all been cleaned up! Now the bounce physics & collision seem fair, predictable... they seem as good as they possibly could be. There's no more times when the ball will go flying in seemingly the wrong direction when you hit it while moving. There's no more instances where the ball seems to clip on corners and fly off in surprising ways. There's even a better drop rate for items like recovery chickens, and they even tweaked the amount of hits it takes to bust blocks in single player or multi player modes to improve the pace of each match and cut down on the tedium early on where you just want to destroy blocks to get some breathing room. Rounds no longer feel like they last a tad too long. This is now super polished and genuinely seems like an ideal version of the game they wanted to execute, and we all wanted it to be. [b]This is post-launch support done right![/b] :) 

The player controls are really fantastic, and its one of those games where it's just fun to control the main character of your choice. There might be [i]a teeny bit[/i] of a learning curve here, but after short while, this goes from "pretty good" to "super fun and addictive". It can get difficult in places (at least until you learn to always prioritize ball return instead of going for power-ups), and you may take awhile to focus on the ball when there's VFX and particles going off everywhere during boss fights, but there's always lots of opportunities to get back in the game thanks to the power-ups enemies and blocks drop anyway. There's no big penalty for failing in the first place (just instantly try again). Its one of those games you end up just playing a bunch without noticing. Even when I lose, I'm finding myself going right back and retrying stages. 

The main mode is also a bit of an "RPG Lite"-style design. With a world map and location "nodes", and a simple premise about going to find your pet presented via cute little cutscenes with sharp, funny dialogue. Its the kind of thing I wish WAY more arcadey games have, since I dug this kind of thing in games like Mario Tennis Power Tour for the GBA or Might & Magic: Clash of Heroes. Its super welcome to see Srikey Sister also frames its arcadey block-breaking action goodness in a mode like that :) 

Basically, Strikey Sisters delivers some big, BIG fun. It sports some really gorgeous faux 16-bit sprite art (no lo-fi, minimalist crap pixel art here!), and absolutely bleeds 90's Japanese game charm (the voiceover work even recalls charming 90's anime too!). Its also got some rocking chiptunes. This is just a really good design, whether you want some arcadey fun for a few hours or to just pick-up-and-play (and lose sometimes, and try again, and again, etc.).

很好玩的遊戲。主地圖的背景音樂一響起，就像是回到了童年。

或許是先入為主的關係，憑著童年打磚塊的記憶，剛上手時覺得有點難，比如無法控制發球位置、抓不準反彈方向等，加上三滴血用完就得整關重來的設定，讓我第一天玩時只能玩到第二關就止步了 ( 你們別這樣，我只是想踢球啊~ )。這個時代提供無限接關應該不為過吧？如果兩人共玩的話，還要共用血的樣子，這... 我想給家裡小朋友安麗一下，一起來玩，但擔心這樣的設計會讓大人小朋友打起來，如果因此成為小朋友的成長陰影真的不太妥當，我老了他們不給我玩遊戲就是你們害的。

剛開始上手雖然打到第二關就止步了，不過我沒有因此退款，因為這遊戲真的很棒。的確想過製作團隊要不要考慮加個休閒模式？或是大爺模式 (100 coins Ready) ？這樣這個遊戲才能更親民，讓實況主推薦給更多手殘人士加入。

不過在看過其他玩家的遊玩影片後 ，第二天繼續玩，這回抓到要領，一路過關斬將，過了11關，擊敗2個魔王，一路欣賞人文風景還真是欲罷不能。敵人與魔王的攻擊模式都設計得很有個性，主人翁持棍反擊的設定 (看我一秒16連擊！) 更讓遊戲有了動作性。總而言之，我對這個遊戲非常滿意！

Em Strikey Sisters, você controlará Marie e Elene, duas irmãs bruxinhas, que tiveram seu animal de estimação, Sachiro, sequestrado. A aventura ocorre de forma bem arcadesca, numa mescla de Puzzle e Ação.

A mecânica base do jogo baseia-se no jogo de SNES de nome Firestriker, onde você controla um personagem com movimentação apenas horizontal, e deve rebater uma bola no cenário para quebrar tijolos.

Além de rebater a bola e mantê-la em jogo para ficar vivo, você pode atacar inimigos diretamente, soltar habilidades especiais, e ainda deve tentar pegar power-ups frequentemente, tornando o desafio bem elevado!

O jogo possui ampla gama de matas, inimigos, padrões e chefes, e também um charmoso mapa para navegar entre as fases... e cutscenes... dubladas!

A cooperação é local para 2 jogadores, exigindo ao menos um joystick para um dos players.

Strikey Sisters es un juego Breakout al estilo arcade. Mucho mapa, desafíos y secretos. Muy divertido tanto en solitario como en cooperativo local. Jugablemente es muy fácil y se pueden configurar los botones para que te sean mas cómodos y juegues a tu manera. Variedad de enemigos y poderes mágicos que sirven mejor o peor según diferentes situaciones. Las peleas de jefes son muy entretenidas y una vez que le agarras la mano esta bueno ir cambiado la dificultad e irte dando cuenta que cosas cambian. Tiene logros muy buenos que le dan mas vida útil al juego y desbloquear el mapa es genial.
Su banda sonora cumple, teniendo algún que otro tema que se te va a quedar pegado por unas horas luego de haberlo jugado. 
Su historia está para decorar, pero como poco es agradable y cuenta con guiños a juegos reconocidos bastante jocosos.
He llegado a notar que veces el efecto "Double Ball" no se activa, y, de vez en cuando, la pelota te pasa por encima como si tu personaje se tratara de un fantasma. No es frecuente, pero me pasó lo suficiente como para darme cuenta de que algo estaba mal.
Muy recomendado para jugar algo divertido con amigxs o pareja.

39507750.review:
Sigh~

I've nearly completed the game in normal mode, so I think I have a pretty clear picture of it for a proper review now. I love and hate it at the same time, and here's why:

Graphics:
[list]
[*]PRO - The art style is spot on and fantastic; it's coherent and gives nostalgic vibes of the 80-90's arcade gaming era, levels show progression in style of pillars and backgrounds as well. Really, it's a work of art. BUT...
[*]CON - We have a bad case of projectile and particle clutter and a major visual design fault at hand. The ball often doesn't stand out at all among the clusterporn of colorfully flashing missiles and drop items (and sometimes its own trail), and it quickly gets very frustrating to keep track of where it is.
[/list]

Sounds:
[list]
[*]PRO - Music fits the gameplay, but all in all it's generic and forgettable. Not something you'd find yourself humming.
[*]PRO - Sounds fit well into this kind of retro arcade genre, BUT...
[*]CON - The absolute retronoisecorevisualkei that accompanies the already cluttered screen so that you don't even hear if the ball has already bounced or not under the pixelpuke it entered.
[*]CON - The voice acting is simply hideous. I've heard zero-budget hentai dubs better than this. And oh boy, don't even get me started on the constant prattling of the bosses during the fight...
[/list]

Levels:
[list]
[*]PRO - Levels are diverse and provide a fair bit of a challenge.
[*]CON - The difficulty curve is mostly a constant.
[/list]

Enemies:
[list]
[*]PRO - There's a LOT of enemies. Every map (except the secrets) introduces a new type of foe to spank. The designers literally went nuts with mixing up the most interesting cocktails of monster skills, from projectile-based attacks through teleportation skills to playing pong with you. They contribute a lot to the immersion. BUT...
[*]CON - The AI is very unbalanced. Sometimes multiple enemies spam you with various skills at the same time, creating an impenetrable obstacle for the player, but there's something way more annoying...
[*]CON - The spawning system is awful. enemies respawn too suddenly and sometimes right over the ball, which will then randomly shoot out of them as they die, or what's even worse, they spawn so close to the bottom that the ball I just hit back would be shot back out of the playfield.
[*]CON - Skill windups are also poorly signaled. The player has very little time to anticipate an ambush-type attack among the random bright flashes cluttering the screen most of the time. There are just too many things to keep track at once.
[/list]

Items:
[list]
[*]PRO - There are quite a few drops you can get from chests or enemies, and all of them are useful in some way.
[/list]

Story:
[list]
[*]CON - Dialogues are generally one-dimensional, repetitive, anticlimactic. The story doesn't develop much. Chasing after a pet and shamelessly causing misery to everyone along the way for barely any justifiable reason makes the protagonists come off as arrogant, bigoted and unrelatable - they are even worse than the boss monsters.
[/list]

Controls, Mechanics:
[list]
[*]PRO - The action is fast and the keyboard controls are responsive. Hit areas are intuitive and sometimes even generous, which makes the player feel more in control.
[*]CON - The game doesn't pause on death, and the ball automatically shoots out after a few seconds of idle time. This means that you have to pause the game manually every time you need to take a break. I found it annoying that I couldn't rage at the screen and properly mourn over my failure before seeing the level fill back up to the brim and trying again.
[/list]

Bugs:
[list]
[*]CON - I have to set full screen mode and "Fit" screen size every time I start the game because it starts in a tiny box in the middle of my screen (on Windows).
[*]CON - Sometimes enemies may leave shadows or particle effects behind if killed at the wrong moment.
[/list]

So, is this game worth its price?
Despite being as frustrating as it gets, Strikey Sisters is still a rich experience and a powerful throwback, and if it's on a discount, it's worth giving a try. Just know when to put it down to cool your head off a bit.

39597631.review:
[h1][b]BESTER BRICK BREAKER SEIT 1987[/b][/h1]

[b]Die Brick Breaker-Idee ist fast so alt wie Computerspiele an sich. Ausgehend vom 1976 erschienen Urvater "Breakout" wurden im darauffolgenden Vierteljahrhundert unzählige Spiele entwickelt, die auf der gleichen Idee basierten. Der bekannteste Vertreter dürfte wohl das 1986 erschienene "Arkanoid" sein. Und der vielleicht interessanteste Vertreter erschien erstmals 1987 für C64 und heißt "Jinks". Ich schätze, das wird kaum jemand kennen (googelt es), aber darauf bezieht sich die Überschrift und es reicht hier zu wissen, dass es sowas wie die WTF-Interpretation des Genres darstellt. Und seit "Jinks" hätte ich mir nicht träumen lassen, dass irgendein Spiel noch irgendwas Bedeutsames zum Thema Brick Breaker beitragen könnte. Ein Irrtum. Aber lest selbst.[/b]

[h1]WIR WOLLEN UNSER HAUSTIER WIEDER HABEN[/h1]

Zuallererst: Strikey Sisters hat eine Story! Sogar stimmig vertont. Natürlich ist diese Story nicht unbedingt Literaturpreisverdächtig, aber sie wird mit viel Witz und Charme in kleinen Zwischensequenzen erzählt und bettet das Spielgeschehen in einen durchaus sinnvollen Kontext. Aber worum geht's jetzt überhaupt? Den beiden Geschwistern Elene und Marie wird eines Tages ihr Haustier Sachiro von einem gewissen Lord Vanik entführt. Und während die mehr zimperliche Elene tränenreich am Boden zerstört ist, fackelt die weniger zimperliche Marie nicht lange und begibt sich mit Elene auf die Suche nach Sachiro. Ab hier übernehmt ihr. 

[h1]EINS, ZWEI, AUF DIE ZWÖLF[/h1]

Eure Suche führt euch durch die gesamte im Fantasy-Setting angesiedelte Spielwelt, die sich in 12 Regionen unterteilt, die wiederum aus 5 Levels bestehen. Dabei erwartet euch in jeder Region ein Boss-Gegner. Sobald ihr euer erstes Level betretet dürft ihr euch dann mit der spielerischen Cleverness von Strikey Sisters anfreunden. Natürlich geht es zunächst auch hier darum, mit einer Kugel Steine abzuräumen, indem ihr sie mit der Kugel trefft. Nur steuert ihr in Strikey Sisters keine flache Plattform (paddle) am unteren Bildschirmrand, an der ihr passiv die Kugel abprallen lasst. Vielmehr spielt ihr eins der zwei Mädels, die per Handstreich eine magische Kugel in die Spielwelt schleudert. Das fühlt sich angenehm ein bisschen wie Baseball an. Warum das jetzt so anders ist? Nun, zum einen benötigt ihr einen Tastendruck, um die Kugel wegzuschleudern. Das fühlt sich schon mal viel weniger passiv an als in herkömmlichen Brick Breakern. Zum anderen lassen sich die Mädels, wahlweise mit Gamepad oder Tastatur, ungleich präziser steuern, als man das vom herkömmlichen paddle gewohnt ist, welches ja im Grunde nix anderes ist, als ein verlängerter und in der Horizontalen gefangener Cursor. Darüber hinaus könnt ihr euch, solange die Kugel nicht eurer Aufmerksamkeit bedarf, mit den auf dem Spielfeld befindlichen Monstern gewalttätig auseinandersetzen. Und das ist ein ebenso spaßiges wie durchdachtes Spielelement. Denn die augenfälligste Schwäche eines Brick Breakers besteht für gewöhnlich darin, dass die Kugel für längere Zeit ziellos durchs Level irrt, weil sich irgendein schwer zu erreichender Stein partout nicht treffen lassen will. Und das verdammt den Spieler zur Passivität. Dieses Ärgernis bleibt bei den Strikey Sisters auf das unumgängliche Minimum reduziert, weil ihr auch noch andere Sachen zu bewältigen habt. Und die Monster, die solange respawnen bis der letzte Stein abgebaut wurde, heizen euch mit so manch fieser Fähigkeit mitunter ganz schön ein. Insbesondere in den Boss-Levels wird der Bildschirm schnell zum regelrechten Kriegsschauplatz. Aber zum Glück seid ihr ja wehrhaft. Geschosse, die auf euer Ableben zielen, können per Schlagtaste geblockt werden. Kommen euch die Monster zu nahe, dann könnt ihr auch einfach auf sie eindreschen. Das kann allein schon zur Befriedigung von sporadisch auftretenden Rachegefühlen nach wiederholter Nahtoderfahrung sehr befreiend wirken. Ihr könnt auch mit einem aufgeladenen Schlag die Geschosse eurer Gegner ins Spielfeld zurückschleudern. Und natürlich könnt ihr auch die obligatorischen PowerUps aufsammeln, die zum Beispiel eure Kugel verlangsamen oder zum Feuerball machen. Ihr könnt auch wirkungsvolle Zauber wie magische Geschosse ergattern, die dann mit Zusatztaste eingesetzt werden. Sehr hilfreich um Gegner zu eliminieren oder schwer erreichbaren Steine zu zerschmettern.              

Der Schwierigkeitsgrad ist bei alledem ürigens nicht zu unterschätzen. Ich empfand meinen Spieldurchlauf zwar insgesamt als recht ausgewogen, mit einerseits genügend Herausforderungen und andererseits weitestgehend frustfreiem und ausreichend flüssigem Spielfortschritt. Zu Anfang war es aber schon recht fordernd. Die in den Optionen verfügbaren Schwierigkeitsstufen verändern übrigens nur die Geschwindigkeit des Spielgeschehens. Fangt am besten mit leicht an und wenn ihr es drauf habt, dann erhöht die Geschwindigkeit. 

[h1]JÄGER UND SAMMLER[/h1]

Als hättet ihr mit Monstern und Bällen nicht schon genug zu tun, könnt ihr in jedem Level auch noch Schätze ergattern. Diese Lagern in Truhen und die Truhen erscheinen auf dem Spielfeld, wenn ihr die erforderliche Anzahl von Münzen eingesammelt habt, die ihrerseits aus zerschmetterten Steinen zum unteren Bildschirmrand purzeln. In den Truhen befinden sich entweder große Edelsteine, die einfach gesammelt werden, oder aber sie enthalten eine Art magische Karte. Diese Karte könnt ihr wie ein Geschoss auf ein Monster abfeuern und wenn ihr es trefft, wird es dem spielinternen Bestiarium zugefügt. Das ist durchaus eine ganz nette und motivierende Nebenbeschäftigung. In einigen Levels befindet sich dann noch eine dritte Truhe. Wenn ihr die findet, dann erhaltet ihr Schlüssel zu versteckten Levels und in einem Fall sogar zu einem neuen Spielabschnitt.

[h1]RETRO JA, ABER 2D-PIXELWAS?[/h1]

Strikey Sisters präsentiert sich komplett im Retrolook. Sowohl grafisch als auch klanglich. Und ich mag das. Der Synthie-Soundtrack und die Pixelgrafik vermitteln sofort dieses alte AMIGA-Feeling, auf dem ich mich nach all den Jahren immer noch irgendwie heimisch fühle. Auch die niedlich animierten Sprites und das in sich stimmige Charakter- und Spielweltdesign gehen so in Ordnung. Was mich etwas stört ist der Begriff Pixel-Art. Wie gesagt, Strikey Sisters ist schön pixelig anzuschauen. Aber Pixel-Art ist das in meinen Augen noch lange nicht. Dafür ist mir das alles einfach zu generisch. Und es soll da ja so 'nen RPG-Baukasten geben, ne? Ist nichts Verwerfliches, aber nochmal: Pixel-Art ist das NICHT!

[h1]MECKERECKE[/h1]

Außer der nicht immer nachvollziehbaren Kollisionsabfrage gibt es ansonsten eher nur Kleinigkeiten zu bemängeln. Die manchmal fehlerbehafteten deutschen Untertitel in den Zwischensequenzen wären da beispielsweise zu nennen, ebenso wie die nicht immer textsynchronen Animationen. Hin und wieder müsst ihr euch auch auf Frustmomente einlassen können. Wie gesagt, einige der gegnerischen Monster sind echt fies. Weniger ein Manko als eine vertane Chance ist der Umstand, dass sich die beiden Geschwister trotz ihres komplett gegensätzlichen Temperaments völlig identisch spielen. Da wurde strategisches Potenzial liegen gelassen, die dem Spiel mehr Abwechslung und der Charakterwahl einen Sinn verliehen hätte. 

[h1]ICH PARSHIPE NICHT![/h1]

Der Vollständigkeit halber soll nicht verschwiegen werden, dass Strikey Sisters im Koop gespielt werden kann. Den konnte ich aus Ermangelung an physisch vorhandenen Spielpartnern nicht wirklich ausprobieren. Ich schätze das aber als ziemlich Spaßige Erfahrung ein. Aber wie es auch sei. Ich betrachte den Koop für dieses Review einfach als das nicht vermisste Schokoladenblatt auf einem supersahnigen Stück Spiel. 

[h1][b][u]FAZIT[/u][/b][/h1]

Mit cleverer Spielmechanik, witziger Story und viel Retrocharme entlocken die "Strikey Sisters" dem vermeintlich ausgereizten Brick Braker-Genre ungeahnte Spielspaß-Qualitäten!
